items.item_details:
2013 Glenn Hoffmann Exemplary Program Award for College Connection Academy (CCA)
	 
https://www.sccoe.org/newsandfacts/newsreleases/2012-13/news042413_videos/franklin.asp
The College Connection Academy is one of several recipients of the 2013 Glenn Hoffmann Exemplary Program Award. The award is named for Glenn W. Hoffmann, who served as the Superintendent of Santa Clara County schools from 1967 to 1984.
A committee of school administrators and board members scored entries from several Santa Clara County school programs. This year, awards were given to the top five programs, which received the highest scores out of 17 total entries.
The demands of our changing economy and the need to foster a more educated workforce inspired the creation of an innovative partnership between the Franklin-McKinley School District, the East Side Union High School District, and Evergreen Valley College. Our three communities will increase the number of first generation college graduates, equipping them with the education and experience they need to succeed in life and family-supporting careers. With the support and involvement of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the College Connection Academy welcomed its first 7th grade class in 2008.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding Selection/Appointment of Measure G, Measure E and Measure I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Members
	 
	 
Every year 7 positions on the 14-member Citizens Bond Oversight Committee are up for renewal or for new appointments.  Under the current ByLaws of the CBOC, members are allowed to serve 2 consecutive two- year terms. To allow for history and consistency and avoid all members terming out at the same time, this rotation process was instituted.
	 
The CBOC is required to have at least seven members that meet the criteria listed below.  
One (1) member shall be active in a business organization representing the business community located within the District.
One (1) member shall be active in a senior citizens’ organization.
One (1) member shall be active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization.
One (1) member shall be the parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district.
One (1) member shall be both a parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the District and be active in a parent-teacher organization, such as the Parent Teacher Association or the School Site Council.
Two (2) members of the community at-large.
No employees or officials of the District can be appointed to the CBOC.  Also vendors, contractors, or consultants of the District are not allowed to serve as members of the Committee.
	 
The 2013/2014 recommended CBOC would be comprised of:
Active in a business organization – Rebecca Gallardo 
Active in a senior citizens’ organization – Ramon Martinez (returning for 2nd term)
Active in a bona fide taxpayer’s organization – Andres Quintero 
Parent / guardian of a child in the district – Cecil Lawson  (returning for 2nd term)  
Parent / guardian of a child in the district and active in a parent-teacher organization – Derek Grasty  (returning for 2nd term)  
Members of the community at large – (at least 2 are required)
Joshua Barousse  
John Delgado 
Betty Duong  (new member) 
Brad Geldert  
Sherry Gilmore 
Mariel Caballero  (new member) 
Rao Tallapragada  (returning for 2nd term) 
Tim Tom  (returning for 2nd term) 
Vince Tran 
The administration would like to thank the following community members for serving on the CBOC.
Martin Reinders
Julio Saucedo
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint the persons to serve on the Measure G, Measure E, and Measure I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee as recommended by Administration.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  14.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget for 2013-2014 
	 
	 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2013-14 Preliminary Budget as recommended. This is the first of three presentations of the Budget to the Governing Board.  The preliminary budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and Superintendent’s Council which provide a basis for the final budget.  The Preliminary Budget Presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s FYE 2012-13 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The FY 2012-13 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance.  After reviewing the fiscal year end 2012-13 summary, major budget assumptions for developing the 2013-14 budget will be discussed including School Services of California dartboard, enrollment and ADA, and salaries and benefits.  The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have not been announced yet and will be presented at the June 11th Governing Board Meeting.  
	 
The preliminary budget presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for the budget year 2013-14 and for the multi-year thru 2015-16 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the District’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 27th meeting. 
  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  14.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Vida Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #20012/2013-31 To Hire Short-Term Non-Certificated Summer Staffing
	 
	 
Routine maintenance, repairs, and grounds related work had been completed on a regular and reoccurring basis prior to significant budget cuts that reduced staffing levels, leaving a backlog of open work orders which have impacted our facilities and the learning environment.  This request for non-certificated short-term summer staff will help ensure that we are able to operate our facilities in an efficient and safe manner when school opens.  In addition, it will enhance the aesthetic, cleanliness, safety and security on school campuses.  This type of work is best done over the summer for ease of access to facilities.     
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$189,971.00   
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G, E, Restricted Maintenance, General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2012/2013-31 to hire short-term non-certificated summer staffing.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Form of Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with ACE Charter School
		 
   
On November 1, 2012, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2013-2014 school year from ACE Charter School (“ACE”).  The District and ACE have been engaged in on-going discussions and ACE has previously accepted the District’s preliminary offer of facilities to ACE at Yerba Buena High School for the 2013-2014 school year.  The District has now prepared a Memorandum of Understanding regarding the facilities to be provided by the District and the terms of use of the facilities by ACE.  
		 
A copy of the form of the MOU presented for Board approval is included.
		           
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
ACE to reimburse the District for its pro rata share of facilities per California Code of Regulations.
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measures G, E and/or I for improvements necessary to provide “reasonably equivalent facilities”.
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attached Facilities MOU between the District and ACE for the 2013-2014 school year.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item 15.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities 
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Measure I Planning and Allocation Process
	 
	 
On November 6, 2012, Santa Clara County voters authorized East Side Union High School District to issue general obligation bonds up to $120 million to upgrade computer/science labs; improve security/safety; repair, equip, and construct classrooms/facilities at Andrew Hill, Calero, Evergreen Valley, Foothill, Independence, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, Yerba Buena, W. C. Overfelt, and District adult, alternative, and charter schools; and acquire property for new schools.  
	 
Measure E Historical Perspective
When Measure E was allocated in 2009, an allocation plan was developed that modeled an intersection between academic programs and renovated and newly constructed facilities, technology and equipment that provided the district with an innovative approach to equitably prioritizing resources.  Specific criteria were developed by a team of stakeholders, including the Academic Master Plan working group, district facility staff, Superintendent and cabinet, School Site Councils, and campus administrators.  A Project Ranking & Pricing Process that is standardized, equitable and stakeholder driven was developed based on the Academic Master Plan categories of Health, Safety & ADA, Capacity, Technology, Outdoor / Athletic Spaces, Collaborative Spaces, and Specialty Spaces.  The Academic Master Plan criteria used to establish standardized criteria for ranking projects was used. The criteria was based on consistency of request, reasonable and affordable, impact on the greatest number of students, timing of projects – long & short, addressing the achievement gap, parity and equity, and cost savings measures.  Sources of District and campus needs were based on the Academic Master Plan, Technology Master Plan, Measure G Master Plan, Preliminary Needs Assessment, Maintenance & Operations Deferred Maintenance Plan, and School Site Council priorities (February 19, 2009, Board Item 13.03).
	 
In that Measure E Equity Distribution process, the Board distributed monies to comprehensive high schools based on three weighted criteria:
Academic Performance Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to the lowest academic performers (30%)
Bond Share Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to campuses that received the least amounts of previous bond measure monies (30%)
Academic Master Plan Distribution:  funds were allocated to specific projects based on School Site Council priorities (20%)
	 
Additionally, the Board distributed monies to:
Alternative Education Distribution (10%)
Technology Distribution (10%)
	 
By 2011, $274,585,000 of bonds had been issued; the remaining $74,415,000 could not be issued due to decreases in property values.  In consideration, the Board approved a Phase III Equity Allocation to mitigate disparity, using Fund 35 and Measure G funds (December 8, 2011, Board Item 14.01).  Phases I and II of Measure E projects are still in progress, and to date no work has commenced on Phase III projects.
	 
Measure I Allocation
In December 2012, the Board allocated $10,500,000 of Measure I Board discretionary funds to augment the Swimming Pool Upgrade Project (December 11, 2012, Board Item 16.03).  In April 2013, the Board allocated $1,000,000 of Measure I Board discretionary funds for the EduCare Silicon Valley facility (April 16, 2013, Board Item 8.02).
	 
In light of the Measure E history and recent authorizations for use of Measure I Board discretionary funds, the following Measure I allocation model is offered for Board consideration.  
	 
Measure I
$120,000,000
Board discretionary allocation for Swimming Pools Modernization Project
$  10,500,000
Board discretionary allocation for EduCare Silicon Valley Early Learning Career Academy
$    1,000,000
Backfill allocations for unissuable Measure E bonds
$  74,415,000
Distribution to Sites
$  34,085,000
	 
	 
Under this proposed Measure I allocation model:
Measure I funds would be used to backfill Board approved site allocations for Measure E.  The proposed use of Measure I to backfill $74,415,000 of unissuable Measure E bonds is not new site allocation; it is a restoration of Board approved allocation from February 2009.  Restoring these funds would facilitate the fulfillment of the original intent of the Board approved site allocations for Measure E.  Refer to Attachment A Capital Improvement Program Budget Overview Summary for a delineation of the sites whose Measure E allocations would be restored; the amounts are listed as “Uncommitted Allocation” for school sites, and as “Land Acquisition” and “Board-Cabinet Contingency” for the District site.  Please note that this Budget Overview Summary is continually updated as completed Measure E projects are closed out and residual budget monies liquidated, which may increase the Uncommitted Allocations at certain sites.  
$34,085,000 of Measure I funds would be allocated to sites in the coming months, following the same weighted criteria system used in February 2009 for Measure E.  
$32,100,000 of Measure I funds used to backfill “Land Acquisition” and “Board-Cabinet Contingency” at the District site would be used to fund and supplement infrastructure projects.  
Since Measure I funds would backfill the $74,415,000 of originally allocated Measure E funds, the “Phase III Equity Allocations” that were Board approved on December 8, 2011, funded by Fund 35 ($2M), Measure G ($2M), State matching funds anticipated in early 2012 ($12M), and State matching funds expected in 2013 ($4M), which were a stopgap measure introduced as a result of the inability to issue the final series of Measure E bonds, could be rescinded; those funds would then be available for District discretionary initiatives.
Future Measure E proceeds from bond sales of $74,415,000 in approximately 2020, when property value increases allow for remaining bond issuances, would become Board discretionary funds.
Measure I Planning Process
	 
An inclusive and collaborative planning process has already begun, to identify needs and develop recommendations for how to use Measure I allocations.  The process would build upon the planning work completed in 2008/2009 for Measure E, and mimic the planning, recommendation and approval process put in place for Measure E, as follows:
	 
Historical Analysis 
A review of past planning initiatives will be conducted to ascertain projects that were identified, prioritized, and either implemented or deferred; those planning initiatives include the 2004 Facilities Master Plan, facilities condition and infrastructure studies, as well as previous Bond Measures A, G and E plans and outcomes.
	 
Infrastructure Condition Studies
Historical infrastructure studies and analysis will be supplemented with additional survey work to identify a global infrastructure strategy for long term needs, with associated cost projections.  The highest priority needs should be included on School Site Council Project and Priority Lists for consideration.
	 
School Site Council Project and Priority Lists 
Historical analysis reports will be reviewed by District and Site administration, and School Site Councils.  School Site Councils will work with Facilities Planning staff to update their project and priority lists.  Project and priority lists will be informed by recommendations identified through the Strategic Planning Initiative.
	 
If School Site Councils require assistance in this matter, Facilities Planning staff may engage professional service providers (such as master planning architects) for assistance.
	 
Superintendent’s Council Engagement
Site project and priority lists will be presented by Site Administration and Facilities Planning to Superintendent’s Council for review and recommendation.
	 
Board of Trustees Approval
Once School Site Council and Superintendent’s Council are aligned on proposed project and priority lists, they will be presented to the Board of Trustees for approval.
	 
Timeline
The following timeline is proposed:
	 
Historical analysis:  April - May 2013
Measure I Allocation Model development and approval:  April – June 2013
Infrastructure condition analysis:  May – September 2013
School Site Council project and priority lists:  May - September 2013
Superintendent’s Council review and recommendation of School Site Council project and priority lists:  October - November 2013
Board of Trustees approval of School Site project and priority lists:  January 2014
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$108,500,000                                                 
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure I general obligation bond funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize distribution of $74,415,000 of Measure I funds to backfill unissuable Measure E bonds, and authorize staff to proceed with the Measure I Planning and Allocation Process and timeline delineated in this report.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item 15.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Proposed Project Labor Agreement (PLA) for Measures G, E & I Projects
	 
	 
East Side Union High School District has been working with the Building Trades Council and its affiliated Unions since 2003 under a Project Labor Agreement for all projects under the Measure G Program.  On December 11, 2008 the Board of Trustees approved the Extension Agreement – Project Labor Agreement for Measure E Bond Projects.  The relationship has been positive as the District continues to be successful with qualified contractors bidding our projects.
	 
As the District embarks on its new Measure I Bond Construction Program, it is necessary and crucial to have a continued pool of qualify contractors and increase the bidding pool for all our projects.  It is critical that District projects continue its pattern of having no labor or other disputes at the job sites and at the same time offer direct career opportunities for ESUHSD students’ within the Trades.  
	 
This Project Labor Agreement has been updated to reflect what’s become standard in other project labor agreements incorporating Appendices A & B.  Continuing with the new Project Labor Agreement for Measures G, E and I will help ensure that the District will have successful construction projects in the future years to come.
                                                                                              
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Specific construction projects funded by Measures G, E & I
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Project Labor Agreement for all projects by the Measures G, E and I Bond Program.

SUBJECT:
Approve the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2013  through March 31, 2013 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any,  filed from January 1, 2013 through March 31, 2013.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve  the First Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering January 1, 2013  through March 31, 2013, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
